claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.

attacks.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.
Switzerland is not a member of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc, not the euro.
While Switzerland is not in the EU, it has bilateral agreements that facilitate euro usage in some border regions and businesses.
The euro is not universally accepted in all parts of Germany and France, as some small businesses may prefer cash or local payment methods.

supporting.text: Switzerland is not part of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.

attacks.text: Switzerland is not part of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.
Some border regions in Switzerland accept euros for convenience, despite the official currency being the Swiss franc.
Acceptance of euros in Swiss border regions is limited and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates or mandatory change in Swiss francs.

supporting.text: France and Germany are founding members of the Eurozone and have adopted the euro as their sole legal tender.

attacks.text: France and Germany are founding members of the Eurozone and have adopted the euro as their sole legal tender.
Switzerland is not a member of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its legal tender.
The claim includes Switzerland, which is factually incorrect as it does not use the euro.
Some regions in France and Germany may still unofficially accept other currencies in border areas.
Unofficial acceptance of other currencies is rare and not legally recognized, so the euro remains the sole legal tender.

supporting.text: While Switzerland is geographically surrounded by Eurozone countries, it maintains its own currency and does not use the euro for domestic transactions.

attacks.text: While Switzerland is geographically surrounded by Eurozone countries, it maintains its own currency and does not use the euro for domestic transactions.
Some businesses in Switzerland, especially near borders, accept euros for convenience, even though the official currency is the Swiss franc.
Acceptance of euros in Switzerland is unofficial and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates, reinforcing that the euro is not the legal tender.
